titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Finding aid prepared by Brian Carpenter

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-09-13T21:18-0400

did.abstract: Field recordings made with Kumiai (Diegueño) speakers from numerous communities in San Diego County, California, and Sonora, Mexico. Primarily consists of traditional stories, including Coyote stories. Also includes word lists, conversations, description of the preparation of acorns for food, identification of museum artifacts, and an extended account of the Mission Indian Federation.
did.physdesc: 3 sound tape reels (6 hr., 34 min.) : analog, 3 3/4 ips, 2 track, mono ; 7 in.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Margaret Langdon in 1970. This material was recorded with the assistance of a Phillips Fund grant.

processinfo.head: Tape transfer information
processinfo.p: The final 35 minutes of tape 2 contain material identical to the first three programs on tape 3 but is of poorer quality and so was not digitized. Tape 1, track 2 begins with 32 minutes of silence that was not transferred when the material was migrated to DAT format. Tape 2, track 2 switches program speed from 3 3/4 ips to 7 1/2 ips from 4:50 to 6:21. Adjustment was made during transfer to DAT.

did.unittitle: Identification of Diegueno artifacts at Museum of Man

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The speaker is identified as a speaker of the Mission Valley dialect. The program contains some print-through of audio elsewhere on the tape.

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals note
originalsloc.p: This file is a compressed, digitized version of the original. The APS Library maintains the original format (Sound tape reel) as well as an uncompressed digitized version of this recording.
